name: Casual Phrases 1
description: Everyday conversation focusing on work, food, plans, and timing nuances across different tenses.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo te va en el trabajo hoy, mi amor?

sideB.text: How is work going today, my love?
How are things at work today, honey?
How's your day at work going, my love?

cards.note:
Uses [How is ... going] to ask about the progress of an activity.

Terms of endearment like [honey], [sweetie], or [my love] are common in casual contexts.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo te está yendo en el trabajo hoy, mi amor?

sideB.text: How is it going for you at work today, my love?
How are you doing at work today, honey?
How is work treating you today, my love?

cards.note: The continuous form [How is it going] emphasizes the ongoing nature of the day.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo te fue en el trabajo hoy?

sideB.text: How was work today?
How did it go at work today?
How did work go today?

cards.note: Past Simple ([How was...], [How did...]) is used because the workday is considered finished or the event is over.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo te ha ido en el trabajo?

sideB.text: How has work been going?
How has it gone at work?
How have things been at work?

cards.note: Present Perfect ([Has been], [Has gone]) connects the past to the present, implying the workday might still be relevant or ongoing.

sideB.text: What are you eating?
What are you having?
What's that you're eating?

cards.note: In English, [having] is a very common synonym for [eating] during meals.

sideB.text: What did you eat?
What did you have?
What did you have for food?

cards.note: Past Simple ([Did you eat]) refers to a specific finished meal.

sideB.text: What have you eaten?
What have you had to eat?
What have you had so far?

cards.note: Present Perfect implies 'up until now' or checking simply if the action happened.

sideB.text: What will you eat?
What will you have?
What are you going to eat?

cards.note: [Will] is used for future decisions made at the moment, or general future.

sideB.text: What are you going to eat?
What are you going to have?
What are you planning to eat?

cards.note: [Going to] implies a plan or intention that already exists.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué cosas te dijeron en el trabajo?

sideB.text: What things did they tell you at work?
What did they say to you at work?
What were you told at work?

cards.note:
[Tell] requires an object (tell you), while [Say] does not (say to you).

The passive [Were you told] is also very common.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué cosas te han dicho en el trabajo?

sideB.text: What have they told you at work?
What things have been said to you at work?
What have they said to you at work?

cards.note: Present Perfect ([Have told]) focuses on the result of the information received recently.

sideB.text: What do you want to watch?
What do you want to see?
What would you like to watch?

cards.note:
[Watch] is used for TV/Movies (moving images).

[See] is used for movies at the cinema or general perception.

sideB.text: What are you watching?
What are you looking at?
What is that you are watching?

cards.note:
Context matters: [Watching] for a show/video.

[Looking at] for a static object or scene.

sideB.text: What did you watch?
What did you see?
What was it that you saw?

cards.note: Use [Did you watch] if asking about a TV show or movie at home.

sideB.text: What did you want to watch?
What were you wanting to see?
What did you want to see?

cards.note: [Did you want] puts the desire in the past (e.g., before we changed the channel).

sideB.text: What would you like to watch?
What would you like to see?
What do you feel like watching?

cards.note:
[Would you like] is a polite way to ask for preference.

[Feel like + -ing] is casual (e.g., 'Do you feel like eating?').

sideB.text: How is work going today?
How is the work coming along today?
How's work today?

cards.note: [Coming along] implies progress.

sideB.text: How is work going today?
How's it going at work today?
How is the job going today?

cards.note: Standard present continuous structure.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo te fue en el trabajo hoy? (Variación)

sideB.text: How did your work day go?
How did it go at work?
How was your day at work?

cards.note: Focuses on the personal experience ([your day]) rather than just the task.

sideB.text: How has work gone today?
How has the work been today?
How has it been going at work?

cards.note: Present Perfect.

sideB.text: Do you want to see me today?
Would you like to see me today?
Do you care to see me today?

cards.note: Direct question about desire/preference.

sideB.text: Will you want to see me today?
Are you going to want to see me today?
Will you be wanting to see me today?

cards.note: Future projection of desire. [Will you be wanting] is a softer, continuous future form.

sideB.text: See you at the terminal.
I'll see you at the terminal.
We'll meet at the terminal.

cards.note:
[See you] is the standard casual goodbye or plan confirmation.

[Terminal] refers to a bus or transport station.

cards.sideA: Nos estamos viendo en el terminal.

sideB.text: We are meeting at the terminal.
We're seeing each other at the terminal.
We are meeting up at the terminal.

cards.note: Present Continuous for future arrangements.

sideB.text: We will see each other at the terminal.
We'll meet at the terminal.
We shall meet at the terminal.

cards.note: [We will see each other] is grammatically correct but [We'll meet] is more common for logistics.

cards.sideA: Vamos a vernos en el terminal.

sideB.text: We are going to see each other at the terminal.
We're going to meet at the terminal.
We are gonna meet up at the terminal.

cards.note:
[Gonna] is the casual pronunciation of [going to].

[Meet up] implies a social or arranged encounter.

sideB.text: Is it necessary to leave early to travel?
Do we need to leave early for the trip?
Is leaving early necessary for traveling?

cards.note: [Do we need to] is more natural in conversation than [Is it necessary to].

sideB.text: Was it necessary to leave early to travel?
Did we need to leave early for the trip?
Was leaving early required for the trip?

cards.note: Past Tense: [Was it] or [Did we need to].

sideB.text: Will it be necessary to leave early to travel?
Will we need to leave early for the trip?
Is it going to be necessary to leave early?

cards.note: Future Tense.

sideB.text: What time do you have to go in?
What time do you have to start work?
At what time do you enter?

cards.note:
[Go in] is the most natural phrasal verb for arriving at work/school.

[Enter] sounds formal or physical (entering a door).

sideB.text: What time did you have to go in?
What time did you have to start?
At what time did you have to enter?

cards.note: Past obligation: [Did you have to].

sideB.text: What time will you have to go in?
What time are you going to have to start?
When will you need to go in?

cards.note: Future obligation.

sideB.text: Are you in a big rush?
Are you in a hurry?
Do you have a lot of rush?

cards.note:
Collocations: [In a rush] or [In a hurry].

'Have haste' is archaic.

sideB.text: Were you in a big rush?
Did you have a lot of haste?
Were you in a hurry?

cards.note: Past state: [Were you].

sideB.text: Were you in a big rush?
Did you used to be in a hurry?
Were you hurrying?

cards.note: Imperfect past in Spanish often maps to Simple Past or Past Continuous in English.

sideB.text: Will you be in a big rush?
Will you be in a hurry?
Are you going to be in a rush?

cards.note: Future state.

sideB.text: Do you exercise today?
Are you exercising today?
Do you work out today?

cards.note:
[Work out] is a very common synonym for [Exercise].

[Are you exercising] implies a future plan for today.

sideB.text: Are you exercising?
Are you working out?
Are you doing exercise right now?

cards.note: Present Continuous for action happening right now.

sideB.text: Did you exercise today?
Did you work out today?
Did you do any exercise today?

cards.note: Simple Past.

sideB.text: Have you exercised today?
Have you worked out today?
Have you done any exercise today?

cards.note: Present Perfect.

sideB.text: Will you exercise today?
Will you work out today?
Are you going to exercise today?

cards.note: Future.

cards.sideA: No como nada en toda la noche.

sideB.text: I don't eat anything all night.
I eat nothing all night.
I'm not eating anything all night.

cards.note:
Present Tense implies a habit (I never do it).

If specifically for tonight, [I'm not eating] is better.

cards.sideA: No comí nada en toda la mañana.

sideB.text: I didn't eat anything all morning.
I ate nothing all morning.
I haven't eaten anything all morning.

cards.note:
[Didn't eat anything] is standard negation.

[Ate nothing] is more emphatic.

cards.sideA: No he comido nada en toda la tarde.

sideB.text: I haven't eaten anything all afternoon.
I haven't had anything to eat all afternoon.
I have eaten nothing all afternoon.

cards.note: Present Perfect works well if the afternoon is not yet over or just finished.

cards.sideA: No comeré nada en toda la mañana.

sideB.text: I won't eat anything all morning.
I will eat nothing all morning.
I'm not going to eat anything all morning.

cards.note: [Won't] = Will not.

cards.sideA: No quiero ver esa película hoy.

sideB.text: I don't want to watch that movie today.
I don't want to see that movie today.
I do not wish to watch that film today.

cards.note: Standard present desire.

sideB.text: I didn't want to watch that movie.
I didn't want to see that film.
I wasn't wanting to watch that movie.

cards.note: Past desire.

sideB.text: I refused to watch that movie.
I didn't want to watch that movie.
I chose not to watch that movie.

cards.note: Nuance: [No quise] in Preterite often implies a refusal or a specific decision made at that moment, unlike [No quería] which is a state of mind.

cards.sideA: No querré ver esa película hoy.

sideB.text: I won't want to watch that movie today.
I will not want to see that film today.
I'm not going to want to watch that movie today.

cards.note: Predicting future feelings.

cards.sideA: No hice ejercicio porque estaba muy cansada.

sideB.text: I didn't exercise because I was very tired.
I didn't work out because I was too tired.
I didn't do any exercise since I was exhausted.

cards.note:
[Exhausted] is a strong synonym for [Very tired].

[Since] can replace [Because].

cards.sideA: No he hecho ejercicio porque he estado muy cansada.

sideB.text: I haven't exercised because I've been very tired.
I haven't worked out because I have been so tired.
I haven't done any exercise because I've been exhausted.

cards.note: Double Present Perfect ([Haven't exercised] + [Have been]) links the recent lack of activity to a recent state of being.

cards.sideA: No haré ejercicio porque estaré muy cansada.

sideB.text: I won't exercise because I will be very tired.
I'm not going to work out because I'll be too tired.
I won't do any exercise because I'll be exhausted.

cards.note: Contractions like [I'll] (I will) make speech more natural.

cards.sideA: Hoy tengo que irme temprano al trabajo.

sideB.text: Today I have to go to work early.
I have to leave early for work today.
I need to go into work early today.

cards.note:
[Leave for work] focuses on the departure.

[Go to work] focuses on the destination.

cards.sideA: Tuve que irme temprano al trabajo.

sideB.text: I had to go to work early.
I had to leave for work early.
I needed to go into work early.

cards.note: Simple Past obligation: [Had to].

cards.sideA: Hoy tenía que irme temprano al trabajo.

sideB.text: Today I was supposed to go to work early.
I had to go to work early today.
I needed to leave early for work today.

cards.note: Imperfect [Tenía que] often implies a plan that may or may not have happened ([Was supposed to]) or a general obligation in the past.

cards.sideA: Hoy tendré que irme temprano al trabajo.

sideB.text: Today I will have to go to work early.
I'll have to leave early for work today.
I'm going to have to go into work early today.

cards.note: Future obligation.

sideB.text: I am arriving at the terminal.
I'm getting to the terminal.
I'm just arriving at the terminal.

cards.note:
[Getting to] is a common casual synonym for [Arriving at].

[At] is used for specific points/locations.

cards.sideA: Llegué al terminal a las cinco en punto.

sideB.text: I arrived at the terminal at five o'clock.
I got to the terminal at five sharp.
I made it to the terminal at five on the dot.

cards.note: [Five sharp] or [On the dot] emphasizes exactness ([En punto]).

cards.sideA: He llegado al terminal a las cinco en punto.

sideB.text: I have arrived at the terminal at five o'clock.
I've got to the terminal at five sharp.
I have made it to the terminal at five on the dot.

cards.note: Grammar Note: In standard English, we rarely use Present Perfect with a specific past time like 'at five'. Simple Past is preferred. However, if emphasized as a recent accomplishment, this structure exists.

cards.sideA: Llegaré al terminal a las cinco en punto.

sideB.text: I will arrive at the terminal at five o'clock.
I'll get to the terminal at five sharp.
I'm going to arrive at the terminal at five on the dot.

cards.note: Future.

cards.sideA: No tengo mucha prisa, puedo esperar por ti.

sideB.text: I'm not in a big rush, I can wait for you.
I don't have much of a hurry, I can wait for you.
I'm not in a hurry, I can wait for you.

cards.note:
[In a rush/hurry] is standard.

[Wait for you] is the correct preposition.

cards.sideA: No tenía mucha prisa, podía esperar por ti.

sideB.text: I wasn't in a big rush, I could wait for you.
I wasn't in a hurry, I could wait for you.
I didn't have to rush, so I could wait for you.

cards.note: Past ability: [Could wait].

cards.sideA: No tendré mucha prisa, podré esperar por ti.

sideB.text: I won't be in a big rush, I will be able to wait for you.
I won't be in a hurry, I'll be able to wait for you.
I won't be rushing, so I can wait for you.

cards.note: Future ability often uses [Will be able to], though [Can] is sometimes used loosely for future.
